Name: bing pian
mei pian
Botanical: Dryobalanops aromatica Gaertn. or Blumen (龍腦香)
Other name: mei hua nao zi 梅花腦子
mei hua pian nao 梅花片腦

Maladies Treated: Fainting due to strokes or heat (中風厥，溫熱昏倒)
Ulceration of the cornea; red eyes with corneal nebula (目赤翳膜)
Mouth sores with erosion (口瘡糜爛)
Angina: chest discomfort and tension because of lack of circulation to the heart muscle; using su bing di wan containing bing pian
Medical Function: Anti–myocardial ischemia: main components borneol and isoborneol exhibit tolerance to hypoxia; su bing di wan containing bing pian increased coronary sinus blood flow, slowed heart rate, and reduced myocardial oxygen consumption in animal experiments
Relieves angina: in clinical experience, su bing di wan containing bing pian relieved chest discomfort and tension due to inadequate circulation to the heart muscle

Antibacterial and preservative: 0.5% bing pian solution inhibited Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci including pneumococcus, and Escherichia coli; inhibited some pathogenic skin fungi; mild preservation effect
Local analgesic: mild local pain-arresting effect with slight stimulation of sensory nerve endings on external use
Promotes delivery: induced delivery in mid-term or late-term pregnant mice (animal)

Sedative: borneol and isoborneol have sedative effects; slight stimulation to sensory nerves; rapid intestinal absorption; crosses the blood–brain barrier within 5 minutes and accumulates for a long time, providing preliminary experimental basis for its aromatic ‘opening the orifices’ effect
Dosage:
Internal: 0.15 g to 0.3 g, usually in pills or powder; seldom used in decoction.
External: apply as fine powder or make into a paste; for washing or added in external medication.
Samples of Formulae:
Bing Pian San (Borneol Powder) [Source: National Patent Chinese Medicines Formulary, Hohhot]
Indications: Mouth and throat pain (口齒咽喉痛).
Composition and preparation: Gypsum (石膏) 60 g (2 liang), Borneol (冰片) 0.3 g (3 fen). Grind into a fine powder.

Usage notes: Internally, mainly used in pills; seldom in decoction. For external application, used for washing formulas or added into external medications.

Su Bing Di Wan (蘇冰滴丸): Composed of equal parts Su He Xiang Zhi (蘇合香脂, storax resin) and Bing Pian (冰片).
Contraindications: Contraindicated during pregnancy and in patients with qi deficiency (氣虛) or blood deficiency (血虛).
Research:
Anti–myocardial ischemia (animal): Containing bing pian, su bing di wan significantly increased coronary sinus blood flow in experimental myocardial infarction dogs, slowed heart rate, and reduced myocardial oxygen consumption; against the decrease in myocardial nutritive blood flow and myocardial ultrastructural changes caused by posterior pituitary hormone, su bing di wan had antagonistic and protective effects.

Clinical observation: In clinical experience, su bing di wan containing bing pian relieved angina, alleviating chest discomfort and tension due to insufficient circulation to the heart muscle.

Antibacterial and preservation: A 0.5% bing pian solution inhibited bacteria and had a mild preservation effect. It inhibited Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci, pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae), and Escherichia coli. It also showed obvious inhibitory effects against some pathogenic skin fungi.

Local analgesia and sensory effects: For external application, it produces a mild local analgesic effect and slight stimulation of sensory nerve endings.

Obstetric effect (animal): It induced delivery in mid-term and late-term pregnant mice.

Sedative and CNS penetration: Borneol and isoborneol have sedative effects. With local application, bing pian provides slight stimulation to sensory nerves. It is rapidly absorbed through the intestine; 5 minutes after administration a large amount can cross the blood–brain barrier, remains for a long time, and the amount is quite high. This provides preliminary experimental evidence for the aromatic ‘opening the orifices’ (芳香開竅) effect.

Geography: Along the sea in the southern part of China near the coast
Maladies Treated: External application: boils, swelling, abscess, carbuncles
Medical Function: Warms the Kidney and fortifies yang
Disperses nodules and reduces swelling
Sex hormone-like effect on the uterus; increases uterine excitability and uterine weight in animals
Immunological activity: promotes normal human peripheral blood lymphocyte proliferation
Anticancer activity in vitro: water extract inhibits human cancer cell lines and induces dose-dependent cancer cell dissolution
Reproductive effects in mice: increases sperm count and motility; mitigates cyclophosphamide-induced declines
Dosage: Internal: 3–9 g. External: appropriate amount; grind to powder and apply to affected areas.
Contraindications: Do not use during pregnancy, or in yinxu (yin deficient) with heat, or in pixu (spleen deficient) conditions, or during colds. Long-term usage may be toxic to the kidney.
Research:
Sex hormone-like effect: adding 50% of the sea dragon infusion 0.5–1.0 ml or 20% of infusion 1.0–2.0 ml in 30 ml Rockwell solution induced rats, mice and rabbits in vitro uterine excitability with enhanced contraction and frequency. A 20% sea dragon intravenous infusion at 2.0 ml/kg to the rabbit excited the in situ rabbit uterus. Compared to vasopressin, sea dragon's uterine-exciting effect is weaker and longer lasting, and unlikely to cause a strong contraction, and in different sexual cycles of the uterus the stimulating effects are similar. The active ingredient that excites the uterus is easily damaged by heat. For Syngnathus acus, the alcohol extract oil solution, the alcohol extract water solution and the water decoction all significantly increased uterine weight in mice; among them the oil solution with alcohol extract was strongest, followed by the water decoction.

Ethanol extracts of Solenognathus hardwickii (刁海龍), Syngnathoides biaculeatus (擬海龍), Syngnathus acus (尖海龍), Cuwen hailong (粗吻海龍), and Hairu yu (海鱰魚), each given by gastric gavage to mice at a daily dose of 3 g/kg, increased mouse sperm count and sperm motility to varying degrees; among these, Solenognathus hardwickii and Syngnathoides biaculeatus had significant effects. The above preparations had no significant effect on weight changes of the genital organs and accessory genital organs of normal male mice. Each preparation inhibited, to varying degrees, the cyclophosphamide-induced decrease in sperm count and decline in sperm motility; among these, Solenognathus hardwickii, Syngnathoides biaculeatus, and Syngnathus acus had significant effects; Solenognathus hardwickii, Syngnathus acus, and Cuwen hailong also significantly increased the prostate weight of the cyclophosphamide model mice.

Immune system effects: 20% hai long gel (20% 海龍膠) at 0.5 ml/animal by gastric gavage in mice significantly increased mouse thymus weight and significantly elevated mouse leukocyte counts; the effect on increasing hemoglobin content in mice was not obvious. The water extract of Syngnathoides biaculeatus promoted proliferation of normal human peripheral blood lymphocytes; the optimal drug amount response was concentrated between 10–20 μl/well, and when the dose increased to 40 μl/well, the stimulatory effect gradually weakened.

Anticancer effects: water decoction of hai long promoted normal human peripheral blood lymphocyte transformation and inhibited human cancer cell lines. Under low-power microscopy, after cancer cells contacted different doses of hai long extract, varying numbers of cell dissolution phenomena were observed; the larger the dose, the higher the rate of cell dissolution, and the leaching out of some intrinsic contents of the cancer cells was more obvious. The water extract of Syngnathoides biaculeatus exhibited inhibitory effects of varying degrees on human cervical cancer cell line (HeLa), ECA190, lung squamous carcinoma, and HCT8 rectal cancer. Hai long showed a certain inhibitory effect on mouse monoamine oxidase B activity and reduced lipid peroxides, but there was no significant difference compared with the control group.

Geography: Temperate and subarctic areas of Asia
Medical Function: Clearing damp-heat; detoxification.
Arresting cough, expectorant and anti-asthmatic effects.
Betulin can inhibit the synthesis of cholesterol and triglycerides, and can effectively prevent obesity, atherosclerosis and type II diabetes.
Anti-cough activity of intraperitoneally injected water, methanol, ether and acid ethanol extracts in mice.
Dosage: Daily dosage: 9 to 15 g, make into powder and mix with liquid. Take orally. External use: appropriate amount.
Samples of Formulae:
For treatment of dysentery: calcine hua shu pi (birch bark) into charcoal. Grind into fine powder. Take 3 g each time, twice a day. 《林氏家抄方》 [1]
For treatment of hot and small amount of urine: use hua shu pi (birch bark) to make a strong decoction. Take orally. 《吉林中草藥》
Contraindications:
Plants can cause systemic toxicity varying from mild abdominal cramping to serious cardiac complications. [3]
[1] Editor note: the original formula mentions using sugar. Sugar can actually induce diarrhea. Sugar should not be use in case of diarrhea.
